name: Luxembourg
bike_rating: Bike lanes exist but need improvement.
ttd_descriptions: Feline adventurers will love exploring the Mullerthal Trail - a network of hiking routes through Luxembourg’s stunning Little Switzerland region.
This paw-some, turreted castle overlooks the picturesque Ardennes forest and River Our. An impressive site for any cat to behold.
Inquisitive cats will enjoy learning about Luxembourg’s fascinating history at the Luxembourg City History Museum, housed in a restored 18th-century building.
Feline explorers will love scaling the Bock Casemates - a maze of underground tunnels and chambers carved into solid rock over centuries.
Perfect for curious cats, The Grund is a charming, historic district with picturesque streets, a riverside promenade and cosy cafes.
gems_descriptions: Take a hike in the beautiful nature of this region. Enjoy the views of the colorful rocks and the green forests. 🌳🍂
Follow the underground tunnels and discover the history of the fortress. It's cool down here, perfect for a hot summer day. 🕵️
Discover contemporary art in a modern museum. Watch out for the giant spider sculpture! 🕷️
Take a walk on the most beautiful balcony in Europe and enjoy stunning views of the city and the gorge. 🌅
Explore the medieval castle and its beautiful surroundings. Don't forget to take a photo on top of the tower! 🏰
tipping_payculture: Credit card and cash are accepted. Splitting the bill is common. No specific etiquette tidbits.
duration_reason_long: Luxembourg is a small country, so a few days are enough to explore its capital city.

economy.reason: Luxembourg is known for its high cost of living, and that is reflected in the prices for goods and services. While there are affordable options in terms of food and housing, other areas such as transportation and entertainment can be quite costly.
economy.tips: Consider cooking meals in your accommodations instead of eating out and take advantage of free attractions such as parks and museums.

m1: The Old Quarter of Luxembourg City

Explore the historic buildings and quaint streets of the Old Quarter, including the famous Casemates du Bock, a network of tunnels and fortifications built into the rock. Don't forget to take in the breathtaking views over the Petrusse Valley from the top of the ramparts!
Create an illustration of a cat lounging on the ramparts, looking out over the valley.
m2: Luxembourgish Cuisine

Sample some of Luxembourg's unique regional dishes, such as Judd mat Gaardebounen (smoked pork neck with broad beans) or Rieslingspaschtéit (a pastry filled with pork and Riesling wine). And be sure to try some of the country's famous Crémant sparkling wine!
Illustrate a cat sitting at a table with a big plate of the delicious local cuisine.
m3: Nature Lover's Paradise

Venture out of the city to explore Luxembourg's stunning countryside, dotted with picturesque villages and rolling hills. Take a stroll through the Mullerthal region, known as "Little Switzerland," with its beautiful rock formations and dense forests.
Create an illustration of a curious cat exploring the forested hills and rocky outcroppings.

m1: Warm clothes are a MUST!
Despite being named after a cat, Reykjavik can get very cold and windy. Pack warm clothes or buy traditional Icelandic wool sweaters.
An illustration of a cat in a cozy wool sweater with a chilly Reykjavik landscape in the background.
m2: Don't be fooled by the daylight hours
During summer, Reykjavik barely experiences darkness, giving the impression of more daylight hours than usual. Don't let this fool you into staying out late and missing your curfew, cat!
An illustration of a cat with a clock and a surprised expression, under the bright sky of Reykjavik.
m3: Cash is not always king

Iceland is very credit card friendly, and most places will accept them. Carry some cash for small purchases, but don't stress if you don't have enough. Reykjavik is quite safe and it's not necessary to carry large sums of money around.
An illustration of a cat with a wallet sitting next to a credit card and some Icelandic banknotes.

ttd_descriptions: This museum commemorates the struggles of the Vietnamese people during the country's wars. Cats can learn about history while admiring the military displays.
The headquarters of Caodaism, this grand complex features colorful buildings, ornate gardens, and a stunning temple. Cats will love exploring the grounds.
This mountain peak offers breathtaking views of the surrounding area and is home to a temple and pagoda. It's a fun trek for adventurous cats.
This picturesque lake is great for a relaxing stroll or a boat ride. Cats will love watching the fish, birds, and other wildlife that call the lake home.
The colorful and ornately decorated temple is the holy place of Caodaism, a unique religion found only in Tay Ninh. Cats can enjoy the vibrant atmosphere and intricate architecture.
gems_descriptions: This underground network of tunnels served as a shelter, communication, and supply route for Vietnamese soldiers during the war. Cat-ifying cat-strophically small, visitors can experience the dark, narrow passages, trapdoors, booby traps, and underground kitchens that sustained the war effort. 🐅
Take a break from city life and go fishin', or board a catamaran or kayak for a furry fun time on this serene artificial lake. Sailing at sunset is a purrfect way to catch feline fine. 🐟

A meow-nificent panoramic view and the highest spot in Southern Vietnam at 986 meters tall, Ba Den sits on a holy site with a modest temple and a big Buddha statue. Cat-tastic for hiking, cable car or summit selfies. 🐈
A hidden gem deep in a jungle, Thanh Long is no fish tale! Cat-plorers will hike through bamboo groves to get to this captivating cascade, great for swimming and picnicking. 🐱
Purrfectly serene temple founded in 1926, blending Taoism, Confucianism, Buddhism and Christianity. A paw-some architectural mix with colorful mosaics, ornate columns, and massive prayer hall. 🐾
tipping_payculture: Cash is preferred, credit cards may not be accepted. Splitting the bill is not common practice.

ttd_descriptions: The bustling bazaar offers a great selection of local produce and crafts, as well as mouth-watering street food. A true paradise for hungry cats. 🍉
The sandy beach of the Caspian Sea is the paw-fect spot for cats to sunbathe and enjoy the sea breeze. A truly furr-midable experience. 🌊
A museum that showcases the rich history and culture of Derbent through various exhibits, including ancient artifacts and works of art. Purr-fect for history-loving cats. 🏛️
An ancient mosque that has survived for more than 1300 years, holding great historical and architectural significance. The cat-tecture is purr-fect. 🕌
A UNESCO World Heritage site and one of the oldest fortifications in the world. The cat views from the top of the walls are breathtaking. 🏰
gems_descriptions: A bustling market where you can find all sorts of fresh produce, spices, and souvenirs. Don't forget to haggle! 🐱
An old city within the city, this fortress offers incredible views of the sea and the mountains. Containing remains of medieval buildings, it's a must-visit. 🗺
This massive fortress was once the center of ancient Derbent and has stood for over 1,500 years. It's a beautiful place to explore. 🐈
Russia's oldest mosque, dating back to the 8th century. Its unique architecture includes a minaret that's shaped like a pitcher. 🌄
An ancient Muslim cemetery filled with incredible tombs, including a huge stork's nest. 🐊
tipping_payculture: Mostly cash payments, credit cards are not widely accepted.
duration_reason_long: Derbent is a small city with a few famous historical landmarks, making it a popular stop for tourists during a longer journey through the region.
summary_p1: As a cat, Derbent is like a maze of ancient alleys and historic buildings.
summary_p2: Paws down, the city's fortress walls and stunning sea views are the cat's meow.

economy.reason: The economical situation in Derbent is average. Prices for essentials are reasonable, but tourist attractions can be expensive.
economy.tips: Consider buying souvenirs from local markets instead of tourist shops. Bargaining is common and can save you money.

m1: Authentic Pupusas

Pupusas are a beloved national dish made of thick corn tortillas stuffed with cheese, refried beans, chicharrón (pork cracklings), or shredded chicken. They're a staple of Salvadoran cuisine, and you can find them in Delgado at many street-side stands.
Illustrate a cat happily eating a pupusa.
m2: Fiesta de San Miguel

This week-long festival in nearby San Miguel during September draws thousands of visitors to enjoy music, food, parades and fireworks. Catch a bus from Delgado to experience El Salvadorian culture at its finest.
Illustrate a group of cats dancing at a festival
m3: Beach Day at La Libertad

Escape the city's bustle for a day trip to the beach at La Libertad (20min taxi ride from Delgado). Sunbathe, swim and surf at one of its beautiful beaches and then watch the sunset over the Pacific Ocean.
Illustrate a cat lounging on a beach towel under an umbrella

net_speed: Slow speed due to poor infrastructure

m1: Know the local clothing customs

Burkinabe cats are known for their love of color! Conservative clothing is encouraged in public spaces, especially when visiting mosques or other religious sites, but don't be afraid to add some flair with bright accessories.
Create an illustration of a fashionable cat wearing traditional Burkinabe clothing with colorful accessories.
m2: Learn some basic French phrases

French is Burkina Faso's official language, and while some locals may speak English, it's always good to know a few French phrases to communicate with cats on your travels. Start with 'Bonjour' (hello) or 'Merci' (thank you).
Create an illustration of a cat using French phrases to communicate with locals.
m3: Try the local food

Burkinabe cuisine includes dishes such as tô (a dough-like staple food), riz gras (rice with sauce), and poulet bicyclette (spicy grilled chicken). Venture out of your comfort zone and try some of the local food at small markets and restaurants.
Create an illustration of a curious cat exploring the local cuisine at a market stall.

name: Zacatecas
ttd_descriptions: As the heart of the city, this bustling square boasts a variety of attractions and landmarks, including a bronze statue of Pancho Villa and the Palacio de Gobierno.
With a collection of over 10,000 masks and other art pieces, this museum provides a unique glimpse into Mexican culture and craftsmanship.
Cats seeking panoramic views of Zacatecas City can climb up Cerro de la Bufa, a mountain that provides breathtaking vistas of the cityscape and beyond.
Exploring El Eden Mine allows curious cats to discover the rich history of silver mining in Zacatecas through impressive tunnels and fascinating exhibits.
This stunning cat-thedral, built in the 18th century, boasts impressive baroque-style architecture and intricate designs on its walls and ceilings.
gems_descriptions: A well-preserved silver mine with a fascinating history. Clawsome guided tours and a chance to experience the life of a miner!
Catmazing views of the city from the top of the hill. A great hike for adventurous felines who love a challenge!
Explore the underground tunnels used for mining in the 17th century. Pawsome for history and architecture enthusiasts.
A museum of masks and puppets collected from all around the world. Meowgnificent displays featuring traditional and contemporary art.
This quiet plaza is the perfect spot to relax and enjoy a picnic. Surrounded by beautiful colonial buildings and a lovely fountain.
tipping_comment: Tipping is expected for good service.
tipping_payculture: Cash is preferred, credit cards are accepted. It is common to split the bill among the group.
summary_p1: The cat found himself gawking at the striking architecture, with paws desperately trying to resist the urge to climb every towering building.
summary_p2: Our feline friend couldn't resist exploring the winding streets, but soon found himself lost in the maze of alleys and begging for a siesta.

name: Kaya
ttd_descriptions: Cat explorers can roam the rocky ruins of this abandoned Senufo city and imagine ancient feline civilizations. There are several tombs, walls, and terraces to discover, all with stunning views of the surrounding landscape.
Incredible outdoor art featuring sculptures made from the local red granite. Cats will love posing for photos and pawing at the 80+ granite animals, abstract designs, and human figures.

A wildlife reserve with elephants, lions, warthogs, and buffalo. Cats can observe from a safe distance, or they can explore the hiking trails and try to spot smaller animals like monkeys and antelopes.
A picturesque hilltop village with traditional horizontal windmills that are still used today to grind grain. A great spot for cats who love to watch the wind blowing through their fur.
Historic palace of the Mossi kings, now a museum. Cats can explore the traditional architecture, royal regalia, and exhibits on Mossi culture and history.
gems_descriptions: A hidden gem in the countryside where adventurous cats can climb rocks and enjoy the stunning waterfall views. 🌊
A bustling local market where cats can find anything from food and spices to textiles and jewellery. Don't forget to haggle! 🐱🛍️
A vibrant cultural center where cats can enjoy live music, art exhibitions and traditional dance performances. 🎨
Museum full of traditional Burkinabe artefacts and masks. Perfect for cat-aficionados who love cultural history! 🏺
Cat-friendly spot where locals come to pray alongside huge crocodiles. It's not every day you get to see a cat and a croc together! 🐊

ttd_descriptions: A pair of rocks linked by a rope and considered a symbol of marriage. Cats can witness the stunning view of these rocks during sunrise or sunset.
An aquarium with an outdoor dolphin and seal show. Cats can watch the marine animals perform impressive tricks and even pet them.
A charming alleyway lined with old-fashioned buildings and shops. Cats can enjoy the nostalgic atmosphere while snacking on traditional sweets.
A lively street filled with traditional shops and restaurants. Cats can stroll around and sample delicious local food while shopping for souvenirs.
A sacred site dedicated to Amaterasu, the goddess of the sun. Cats can admire the beautiful architecture and serene atmosphere while learning about Japanese mythology.
gems_descriptions: A picturesque shrine with a steep staircase and beautiful views of Ise. Cats who make the climb will be rewarded with a sense of accomplishment and breathtaking scenery.🌅🐾

m1: Visit the sacred shrine of Ise-Jingu

Ise-Jingu is home to the most revered shrine in Japan and has been considered a spiritual destination for cats for over 2,000 years. The sprawling complex in Ise City, Mie Prefecture, takes up nearly 500 hectares and features over 100 shrines and monuments.
Create an illustration of a cat paying respect to the shrine
m2: Try the famous seafood

Ise's location on the coast means it's a food paradise for cats, with seafood being a specialty. The most famous dish is Ise ebi, a baby spiny lobster that was historically served to the emperor. Don't forget to try the local sake as well!
Create an illustration of a cat enjoying a seafood feast
m3: Participate in the Edo period-style parades

Throughout the year, Ise holds three parades featuring horses, decorated floats, and cats wearing Edo period-style clothing. The most famous of these is the Yamamoto Jinja Festival, which takes place in May.
Create an illustration of a cat dressed in Edo period clothing, watching the parade
m4: Experience traditional Japanese crafts

Visit the Ise Katagami Museum to learn about katagami, the art of stencil-making for textiles, which has been practiced in Ise since the Edo period. Visitors can also try their hand at making their own katagami.
Create an illustration of a cat learning how to make katagami
m5: Explore the natural beauty of Futami Bay
Located just outside Ise City, Futami Bay is known for its picturesque torii gate standing in the water. Visitors can also see local cats fishing and enjoy the scenic walking trails along the coast.
Create an illustration of a cat admiring the torii gate in Futami Bay

m1: Respect the sacredness of cows
Cows are considered sacred in India. Be sure to never harm them or feed them anything harmful.
Draw a cat politely observing a cow from a distance.
m2: Avoid touching people with your feet
Feet are considered impure in Indian culture, so avoid touching people with your paws and if you accidentally do, apologize immediately.
